qas.question: Which type of intellectual property is secret?
What law do most US states use to protect trade secrets?
What US federal law protects trade secrets?
Commonwealth common law regards trade secrets as what kind of right?
US law regards trade secrets as what kind of right?
What secrets this federal law protect?
What do most US states use the Economic Espionage Act to protect?
What does federal law protect using the Uniform Trade Secrets Act?

plausible_answers.text: theft or misappropriation of a trade secret

qas.question: What does the Unified Trade Secrets Act make a federal crime?
What is criminalized by the United Trade Secrets Act when for the benefit of a foreign power?

context: <b5_0>Trade secret<b5_0/> misappropriation is different from violations of other intellectual property laws, since by definition <a0_0>trade secrets<a0_0/> are secret, while patents and registered copyrights and trademarks are publicly available. In the United States, <b6_0>trade secrets<b6_0/> are protected under state law, and states have nearly universally adopted the <a1_0>Uniform Trade Secrets Act<a1_0/>. The United States also has federal law in the form of the <a2_0>Economic Espionage Act<a2_0/> of 1996 (18 U.S.C. §§ 1831–1839), which makes the <b8_0>theft or misappropriation of a <b7_0>trade secret<b8_0/><b7_0/> a federal crime. This law contains two provisions criminalizing two sorts of activity. The first, 18 U.S.C. § 1831(a), criminalizes the <b9_0>theft of trade secrets<b9_0/> to benefit foreign powers. The second, 18 U.S.C. § 1832, criminalizes their theft for commercial or economic purposes. (The statutory penalties are different for the two offenses.) In Commonwealth common law jurisdictions, confidentiality and trade secrets are regarded as <a3_0>an equitable right<a3_0/> rather than <a4_0>a property right<a4_0/> but penalties for theft are roughly the same as the United States.[citation needed]
